subject: Personal Finance
title: The Sunk Cost Fallacy
description: A 60-second lesson on The Sunk Cost Fallacy.

hook.text: You've sat through a terrible movie for an hour. You stay because you paid for the ticket.

buildup.text: Sunk costs are expenses already spent that can't be recovered no matter what you do next.

discovery.text: Rational decisions should ignore past costs and focus only on future value.

twist.text: Companies pour billions into failing projects because they've already started them.

climax.text: The Concorde jet flew for 27 years at a loss. Governments couldn't quit after investing so much.

punchline.text: What you've spent shouldn't dictate what's next.

quiz.question: Why is the Concorde jet often linked to the sunk cost fallacy?
options: Governments kept funding it despite losses
It was too expensive to build
Passengers refused to fly on it
